headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE second quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Mr. Steve Iaco with Investor Relations. Thank you. You ma
componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE second quarter earnings call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Mr. Steve Iaco with Investor Relations. Thank you. You may begin.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This conference call
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This conference call is being webcast and is available on the Investor Relations section of our website. A presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks, can also be found there. An audio archive of the webcast will be posted on the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow.
Please turn to the slide labeled forward-looking statements. This presentation contain statements that are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, financial performance, business outlook, adjusted earnings per share expectations, expectations regarding our government-sponsored enterprise lending activities, the timing of incentive fee realizations and our ability to close and integrate the Global Workplace Solutions acquisition, including the timing of that closing.
These statements should be considered estimates only and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any of the forward-looking statements you may hear today.
For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our second quarter earnings report filed in Form 8-K and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q and annual report on Form 10-K.
These reports are filed with the SEC and are available at sec.gov. During this presentation, we may make certain statements that refer to non-GAAP financial measures, as defined by SEC regulations. Where required by these regulations, we may provide reconciliations of these measures to what we believe are the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Those reconciliations, together with explanations of these measures, can be found within the appendix of this presentation or in our earnings release.
Please turn to Slide 3. Participating on the call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our Chief Financial Officer and Director -- Global Director of Corporate Development; and Gil Borok, our Deputy Chief Financial Officer and Chief Accounting Officer.
During our remarks, all references to the percentage increase or decrease in revenue are in local currency, except or otherwise noted. 
Now please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. CBRE's excellent start to 2015 extended into the second quarter. Our business exhibited broad strength around the world, and we continue to execute our strategy and our people create real, competitive advantag
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve, and good morning, everyone. CBRE's excellent start to 2015 extended into the second quarter. Our business exhibited broad strength around the world, and we continue to execute our strategy and our people create real, competitive advantages for our clients. We were pleased to once again produce double-digit growth rates on the top and bottom lines. Our growth was especially impressive coming at a time when foreign currency exchange rates worked against us significantly.
In local currency, our increases of 19% in revenue and 22% in normalized EBITDA are among our best on record. Adjusted earnings per share, while up strongly at 17%, would've increased by more than 30% but for the currency effects. Our regional services businesses, the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific, drove our strong performance during the quarter.
We continue to invest prudently in recruiting, M&A, platform enhancements and strategic initiatives to ensure that we are always providing best in class service for our clients and driving profitable growth for our business. The benefits of these efforts were very clear in the second quarter. Each of our 3 regions turned in exceptional results with high teens or better revenue growth in local currency, positive operating leverage and strong margins.
While achieving robust growth and remaining riveted on client service, we continued our progress toward completing the acquisition of the Global Workplace Solutions business from Johnson Controls. We remain on course to complete this transaction later this quarter or early next quarter and are very enthusiastic about the opportunities it will afford us to deepen our relationships with many of the world's largest corporations.
A final highlight of the quarter was CBRE's performance in the bearings 500 ranking published in May. Bearings uses detailed analytics to evaluate the financial performance of the 500 largest U.S. based corporations. We are extremely pleased to be number 2 on this prestigious ranking this year, up from number 7 last year. This is a great testament to the hard work our people are doing everyday to create value for our clients and our shareholders.
Now I'll turn the call over to Jim who will describe our second quarter performance in greater detail.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5. As Bob indicated, our Q2 results reflect sustained, underlying momentum in our business. We are in a very good financial position, with market-leading scale, strong margins, robust cash flow and a flexible investmen
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. Please turn to Slide 5. As Bob indicated, our Q2 results reflect sustained, underlying momentum in our business. We are in a very good financial position, with market-leading scale, strong margins, robust cash flow and a flexible investment grade balance sheet. Reflecting this, Standard & Poor's recently raised our investment grade rating to BBB from BBB minus.
Revenue and earnings achieved strong, double-digit growth, even after adverse foreign currency movement. Gross revenue and fee revenue both rose 12% or 19% in local currency. Normalized EBITDA increased 16% or 22% in local currency to $304 million.
We achieved a 17.1% normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue, up 60 basis points from Q2 2014. Adjusted earnings per share improved 17% to $0.42 for the quarter, after a $0.05 negative impact from adverse foreign currency movement. Adjusted earnings per share would've improved 31% without the effects of foreign currency.
Please turn to Slide 6 for a review of the performance of our major global lines of business in Q2. As a reminder, all percentage increases are in local currency unless noted otherwise. We achieved outstanding growth in our capital markets business. Property sales revenue surged 32% with growth in the vast majority of countries worldwide. Mortgage services revenue growth exceeded 40% for the second quarter in a row. Mortgage servicing rights on loan activity associated with the U.S. government-sponsored enterprises or GSEs continue to grow rapidly, with EBITDA up $14 million over last year's Q2. As we indicated last quarter, GSE activity is expected to moderate in the second half of the year due to regulatory caps.
Global Corporate Services, our occupier outsourcing business, was particularly strong overseas as clients increasingly require globally integrated solutions. Excluding the transaction revenues generated by this business, we are accounting -- which are accounted for in leasing and sales revenues, Global Corporate Services achieved a 15% increase in fee revenue.
Asset services also showed robust growth around the world, with fee revenue up 24%. Property leasing revenue jumped 15% as our focus on market share gains continued to pay dividends. Evaluation business line had a very strong quarter, with revenue up 35%. Every region exhibited double-digit growth even before accounting for acquisitions completed in the second half of last year.
Revenue fell in Global Investment Management, in part due to minimal carried interest and incentive fees in this year's Q2. Overall, contractual fee revenue, plus leasing, which is largely recurring, totaled 68% of total fee revenue. Property sales accounted for 23% of total fee revenue.
Please turn to Slide #7, where we will review Q2 results for our 3 regional business services segments, starting with the Americas. The Americas, again, displayed strength across the board as overall fee revenue increased 19% to $1.06 billion. Every business line in the region produced double-digit revenue growth for the fourth quarter in a row. Once again, capital markets turned in a very strong performance. Property sales rose 25%, with major contributions from the U.S. and Mexico, while mortgage services improved 44%. We increased our market share in the U.S. investment sales and held the number 1 position at midyear, according to RCA. Leasing revenue grew at a double-digit clip for the eighth consecutive quarter. This reflects both improved productivity from our current brokers, as well as contributions from new producers where migrating to CBRE at an impressive rate. Revenue for the quarter was up 11%. Combined fee revenue from Global Corporate Services and asset services improved 11%.
Please turn to Slide 8 regarding EMEA. EMEA's performance rebounded significantly following a sluggish start to 2015. Fee revenue growth was robust across every service line and increased 33% overall to $409 million. Property sales revenue surged 62%. United Kingdom showed exceptionally strong growth with France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Sweden also making notable gains. France recovered from a relatively low base in Q2 last year and remains a challenging macro environment. For the region, our growth markedly exceeded the estimated 19% volume growth recorded for the market as a whole. Growth in leasing was exceptional. Big gains in Germany, the United Kingdom and other countries resulted in a 33% increase in leasing revenue. Year-to-date, leasing is up 14%. Combined fee revenue from Global Corporate Services and asset services also achieved very strong growth, improving 25%. The United Kingdom accounted for the lion's share of this growth, with notable contributions from France, Germany and Spain.
Please turn to Slide 9, regarding Asia Pacific. This region achieved 17% growth in fee revenue to $200 million. Property sales revenue increased 24%, led by strong growth in Australia and Greater China. This was a notable improvement from a relatively soft Q1. Leasing revenue also rose solidly, increasing by 12%. Australia, India and Singapore all posted healthy gains. Combined fee revenue from Global Corporate Services and asset services rose 19%. China and India were key growth drivers as outsourcing continues to gain a firmer foothold in these emerging economies.
Please turn to Slide #10, regarding our occupier outsourcing business. Financial results for this business line, which we call Global Corporate Services, are reported within the 3 regional services segments. Global Corporate Services grew 15%, continuing its long-term record of solid, secular growth as we focus on extending our leadership position with deeper and broader services for our clients. The payoff can be seen in a growing roster of clients and the expansion of existing relationships. In Q2, we signed 83 total outsourcing contracts, one of our most productive quarters and nearly 40% entailed expanding services or geographies for existing customers. Mission-critical facilities have provided further ground for growth since we added the Norland capabilities 18 months ago. To illustrate, we were awarded data center management contracts with 2 Fortune 50 companies and the global financial information company during the quarter. Adding Global Workplace Solutions 16,000 people in more than 50 countries later this year will further broaden our reach and deepen our expertise.
Please turn to Slide 11, regarding our Global Investment Management segment. Revenue and normalized EBITDA in Global Investment Management decline in Q2 versus the prior year. This was driven disproportionately by minimal carried interest and incentive payments, as well as the impact of the weak market in the quarter. The MSCI U.S. REIT Index declined 10% during Q2 2015 as compared to a 7% increase in the index during the prior year second quarter. As a result, we did not achieve anticipated incentive fees in our listed securities business and we're impacted by the mark-to-market of our related co-investments. Overall, combined incentive fees and carried interests are expected to be more weighted at the second half of this year. We anticipate being on track with our Investment Management and Development Services combined guidance for the full year. Capital raise -- capital raising continued at a brisk pace. We raised $2.2 billion in the second quarter and $7.7 billion over trailing 4 quarters. The pipeline remains strong as we continue to produce solid returns for investors. Assets Under Management of $88.4 billion were up $2.1 billion over prior year Q2 in local currency, but down $4.4 billion when converted into U.S. dollars.
Please turn to Slide 12, regarding our Development Services segment. You will recall, we expected property sales and earnings in this business to be weighted to the second half of the year. Development projects in process totaled $6 billion, up $500 million over Q1 2015 and the pipeline totaled $3.7 billion, up over $100 million over Q1 2015.
Please turn to Slide 13 as I turn the call back over to Bob for closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. At the midpoint of 2015, CBRE is on course for another year of very strong financial performance. We are intensely focused on executing our strategy to sustain long-term secular growth and further extend our position as the industry leader
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. At the midpoint of 2015, CBRE is on course for another year of very strong financial performance. We are intensely focused on executing our strategy to sustain long-term secular growth and further extend our position as the industry leader.
During the first half of 2015, we completed 3 infill acquisitions that enhanced our service offering, and we continued to lay the groundwork for the smooth integration of Global Workplace Solutions later this year. This business is perfectly aligned with our strategy of helping large global clients to meet their objectives under long-term contractual relationships.
We also continued to selectively upgrade and expand our talent base. Brokerage recruiting is running at a brisk pace again this year. We are capitalizing on the growing recognition that CBRE affords the industry's top professionals the opportunity to better serve their clients and build their careers.
Finally, as Jim reviewed earlier, we are in a very strong position financially. As we start the second half, we are positive on our outlook for the remainder of 2015 and believe our full year performance is likely to be toward the upper end of our guidance range of $1.90 to $1.95 adjusted earnings per share.
Our business has positive underlying momentum, and we are seeing great benefit from the steps we have taken to enhance our service delivery for clients and fortify our market position.
Operator, we'll now open the line for questions.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from the line of Tony Paolone with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions]  Our first question comes from the line of Tony Paolone with JPMorgan.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give us maybe some guideposts on EMEA, particularly sales and leasing, for the back half of the year in terms of, are those -- you see those as being easier, more difficult comps, because when I look at sort of the performance in the second quarte
componenttext: Can you give us maybe some guideposts on EMEA, particularly sales and leasing, for the back half of the year in terms of, are those -- you see those as being easier, more difficult comps, because when I look at sort of the performance in the second quarter, it's pretty strong, but it's also seems to be part of the business where you might be most subject to currency as well? So just trying to understand what that picture looks like in the next couple quarters.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tony, good morning. This is Bob. We did have a good quarter in EMEA after a tough quarter, as you know, and that part of the world is particularly impacted by FX. The business has picked up momentum, and we believe that we'll have a strong second half the
componenttext: Tony, good morning. This is Bob. We did have a good quarter in EMEA after a tough quarter, as you know, and that part of the world is particularly impacted by FX. The business has picked up momentum, and we believe that we'll have a strong second half there. Obviously, we're not providing separate guidance on what might happen in any one of our geographic regions, but we do feel good about the momentum in the business, and it goes beyond the U.K. We're seeing good momentum in several of the other countries, as Jim noted in his comments. So we should see good second half there.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then second, in the Americas, your leasing was up 10%. It's a good number. But I'm just curious what your thoughts are in terms of how you see that commission pot cyclically and what you think the potential might be over the balance of the cycle
componenttext: Okay. And then second, in the Americas, your leasing was up 10%. It's a good number. But I'm just curious what your thoughts are in terms of how you see that commission pot cyclically and what you think the potential might be over the balance of the cycle, say, because it seems like that's one of the business lines in regions where it just doesn't -- hasn't seem like it's run to its potential yet this cycle.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tony, this is Jim. I think we're up now 8 quarters double-digit leasing in the Americas. So it's still relatively early in the recovery stage, but it continues to move strongly. I think it was up 11% in local currency, and we're up probably 15% year-to-da
componenttext: Tony, this is Jim. I think we're up now 8 quarters double-digit leasing in the Americas. So it's still relatively early in the recovery stage, but it continues to move strongly. I think it was up 11% in local currency, and we're up probably 15% year-to-date. So I think it's pretty consistent with our guidance for the year, so far, on the leasing.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Do you feel like that business is far along, say, as investment sales or if you feel like there's still a lot more to be gained on the leasing side?
componenttext: Do you feel like that business is far along, say, as investment sales or if you feel like there's still a lot more to be gained on the leasing side?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think leasing is still in relatively early stages. If you think back, we've only recovered the jobs we lost in the last recession, in April of last year. And I think it's the pickup in jobs that's been at a modest pace but steady that's helped solely im
componenttext: I think leasing is still in relatively early stages. If you think back, we've only recovered the jobs we lost in the last recession, in April of last year. And I think it's the pickup in jobs that's been at a modest pace but steady that's helped solely improve rental rates, and that's provided some fuel behind the business. But it feels relatively early still.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and last question with regards to the JCI transaction, any update on financing and when you think you might -- I think, if I recall correctly and I might be wrong, but you're going to fund a part of it with and just wondering when you start to put t
componenttext: Okay, and last question with regards to the JCI transaction, any update on financing and when you think you might -- I think, if I recall correctly and I might be wrong, but you're going to fund a part of it with and just wondering when you start to put that all together.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: When we announced the deal, we mentioned that we anticipated funding some of it with cash, probably somewhere in the range of about 1/3 and the rest with debt. And we can't provide more insight in that right now.
componenttext: When we announced the deal, we mentioned that we anticipated funding some of it with cash, probably somewhere in the range of about 1/3 and the rest with debt. And we can't provide more insight in that right now.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brad Burke with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brad Burke with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: A bit of a follow-up to Tony's questions, but more macro there. I guess the negative headlines that we're seeing coming out of Greece or China haven't had much of an impact on the results, but for the impact of FX, and I'm just wondering if we should star
componenttext: A bit of a follow-up to Tony's questions, but more macro there. I guess the negative headlines that we're seeing coming out of Greece or China haven't had much of an impact on the results, but for the impact of FX, and I'm just wondering if we should start to sense -- see any moderation or slowdown outside the U.S. across any of your business lines because of macro concerns? Or at this point of the CRE market, just shrugging it off?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brad, I was over in Europe last week with our EMEA leadership team, and they are not feeling threatened by the macro circumstances you're describing. Obviously, they're watching them and they're watching more closely than we do from over here and they hav
componenttext: Brad, I was over in Europe last week with our EMEA leadership team, and they are not feeling threatened by the macro circumstances you're describing. Obviously, they're watching them and they're watching more closely than we do from over here and they have insight from interface with local business people and so forth. But they're not feeling threatened by that. And in general, feeling good momentum, as I said to Tony, good momentum, not only in the U.K. but in businesses around Europe. So you never know where surprises might come from, but for the moment, everything we're seeing is being taken on board and that economy, broadly speaking, is now growing and activity in our sector's picking up, leasing as well as capital markets, which has already picked up. So we're feeling pretty good about it right now.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that will be the same for Asia Pacific as well?
componenttext: And that will be the same for Asia Pacific as well?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Asia Pacific, situation is a little different in Asia Pacific than it is in EMEA. Everything's relative, so our folks in Asia Pacific, while that part of the world is still growing faster than the rest of the world relative to historic standards, it's not
componenttext: Asia Pacific, situation is a little different in Asia Pacific than it is in EMEA. Everything's relative, so our folks in Asia Pacific, while that part of the world is still growing faster than the rest of the world relative to historic standards, it's not as exciting. So I would say that they're feeling solid, but there's not the same enthusiasm about the relative movement in the market as there is in EMEA. And of course, the leasing, in general, is moving solid, not spectacular in Asia Pacific. Capital markets, a lot of capital wants to go there. There's a challenge around lack of product in some markets. So I think there's not a feeling of being threatened by the macro circumstances there. But on a relative basis, EMEA probably has a little more momentum now than Asia Pacific.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And Jim, I think you said you realized a $14 million improvement in EBITDA from GSE lending in the quarter but you're still expecting there'd be a deceleration in the back half of the year. So I was hoping you could help us think abo
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And Jim, I think you said you realized a $14 million improvement in EBITDA from GSE lending in the quarter but you're still expecting there'd be a deceleration in the back half of the year. So I was hoping you could help us think about the magnitude of the slowdown that you might expect and if you can give us any rough guidelines on how you think about the potential EBITDA impact year-over-year.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a little hard to predict the volume, but we do think we'll be down in the second half versus the prior year, probably in the range of $10 million to $20 million, but that's our best view as of now.
componenttext: Yes. It's a little hard to predict the volume, but we do think we'll be down in the second half versus the prior year, probably in the range of $10 million to $20 million, but that's our best view as of now.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And on Investment Management EBITDA, I realized that a lot of the decline that we're seeing is driven by some of the choppier items, but still the lowest quarter that we've seen in a while, so I was hoping you could think us help us think about what
componenttext: Okay. And on Investment Management EBITDA, I realized that a lot of the decline that we're seeing is driven by some of the choppier items, but still the lowest quarter that we've seen in a while, so I was hoping you could think us help us think about what you're looking at in 2Q and how that compares to how we should think about the normalized run rate for that business.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Q2 was definitely hit by a number of things, I would say. The performance of the REIT market was a big one. It was down over 10%. The market index was down over 10% in Q2 and that's compared to being up 7% in Q2 on the prior year. So that compare -
componenttext: Right. Q2 was definitely hit by a number of things, I would say. The performance of the REIT market was a big one. It was down over 10%. The market index was down over 10% in Q2 and that's compared to being up 7% in Q2 on the prior year. So that compare -- and that compare hits us in a few different places. It resulted in us not achieving some incentives that we had anticipated. It reduced some of the fees off the base business, and then that 17% swing resulted in us marking the market our co-investments, which was not immaterial with about $60 million or so of co-investments in that business. So the combination of those 3, I would say, was somewhat of an anomalistic impact. FX also hit the businesses. It's pretty heavily weighted to Europe, so I think those are the primary factors that hit it for the quarter. And as I said in the opening, we do believe that our guidance for the year, which we gave on a combined basis for the development business and the Investment Management business, was still -- still appears to be on track.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Mitch Germain with JMP Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Mitch Germain with JMP Securities.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just curious on the guidance, is that including the impact of the GWS acquisition?
componenttext: Just curious on the guidance, is that including the impact of the GWS acquisition?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It is. But we're not expecting that to have a material swing on the numbers for the period of time that we'll have the business.
componenttext: It is. But we're not expecting that to have a material swing on the numbers for the period of time that we'll have the business.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the 1 quarter is not going to make much of a difference? So then how should we think about it for next year then?
componenttext: So the 1 quarter is not going to make much of a difference? So then how should we think about it for next year then?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We won't be giving guidance on that for next year until we're ready to give guidance for the year, just in kind of our normal course of activity.
componenttext: We won't be giving guidance on that for next year until we're ready to give guidance for the year, just in kind of our normal course of activity.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just with regards to GWS, how many new relationships does that company bring in to the fold.
componenttext: And then just with regards to GWS, how many new relationships does that company bring in to the fold.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mitch, it brings in 100 relationships, many of which we have already, 100 plus relationships. But many of those, we don't have on a contractual basis. So as you know, we, because of the scale of our business, we do business in one way or another with most
componenttext: Mitch, it brings in 100 relationships, many of which we have already, 100 plus relationships. But many of those, we don't have on a contractual basis. So as you know, we, because of the scale of our business, we do business in one way or another with most companies around the world today. But GWS had large contractual relationships with a substantial number of corporations that we had one-off relationships with. So very, very different relationships going forward and a very important part of this deal.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just in terms of that comment, Bob, how do you consider the potential to cross sell if many of those customers are already existing customers? Just trying to figure out kind of what -- not just what GWS brings into the fold but what it could bring in y
componenttext: So just in terms of that comment, Bob, how do you consider the potential to cross sell if many of those customers are already existing customers? Just trying to figure out kind of what -- not just what GWS brings into the fold but what it could bring in your ability to cross sell your services.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's two kinds of cross sell that'll come from that combination. One is what GWS can do for the clients we have that we're not doing today, and then the other is what we can do for the clients they have that they're not doing today, so there's big oppo
componenttext: There's two kinds of cross sell that'll come from that combination. One is what GWS can do for the clients we have that we're not doing today, and then the other is what we can do for the clients they have that they're not doing today, so there's big opportunity in both directions. The first order of business, of course, is for us to get the businesses combined and do great work with what we're already doing and that's where our focus is right now. But we do think there's both kinds of revenue synergy opportunities. There's technical services that GWS should be able to provide for us in many places in the world and many clients and then obviously, they didn't have a material transaction business and we think there's opportunity if we do great work for those clients over time to do quite a bit of transaction work for them. So we look at that in both directions, but the starting point is great job of what we're already doing for those clients.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just in terms of appetite for acquisitions. I think you mentioned 3 on the year. Is it slowing down as you -- just because you kind of got this big one in the Q? Or is it still as active a pipeline as you guys have seen before?
componenttext: Okay. Just in terms of appetite for acquisitions. I think you mentioned 3 on the year. Is it slowing down as you -- just because you kind of got this big one in the Q? Or is it still as active a pipeline as you guys have seen before?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say the pipeline's just as active. As we've commented over the last year or so, we've become increasingly particular about the deals and the deal structures that we're looking at, walking away from deals that we think the pricing is out of rack. B
componenttext: I would say the pipeline's just as active. As we've commented over the last year or so, we've become increasingly particular about the deals and the deal structures that we're looking at, walking away from deals that we think the pricing is out of rack. But the pipeline is still quite solid. We signed GWS in the first half and closed 3 infill acquisitions, slightly slower pace than normally without a large transaction. But I think we feel pretty good about the pipeline, and we'll continue to do infill, probably at a pretty similar rate to what we've done when we're not in the midst of a large closing.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, we don't have that. That's a great question, and it'd be nice to have that statistic at our fingertips, but we don't. And so we can't answer it specifically. I'll tell you what we are seeing. Prices are good, so a lot of people are trading, and the
componenttext: David, we don't have that. That's a great question, and it'd be nice to have that statistic at our fingertips, but we don't. And so we can't answer it specifically. I'll tell you what we are seeing. Prices are good, so a lot of people are trading, and there's a lot of capital out there. So a lot of people are trading as part of why prices are good. But there's also -- once people acquire assets, there's a desire to keep them and work them, so on and so forth. So you have dynamics on both sides of that question, some pushing for quick turnover, some pushing for longer hold, and where the math works out, we just don't have -- we haven't researched that and don't have an answer ready for you.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Brandon, it's consistent with the last couple of years, and we've commented that last years have been kind of long-term records for us. So we're encouraged by it. We're not really surprised by it because we work very hard at it, and we've done some
componenttext: Well, Brandon, it's consistent with the last couple of years, and we've commented that last years have been kind of long-term records for us. So we're encouraged by it. We're not really surprised by it because we work very hard at it, and we've done some things with the business that make it a more attractive place for brokers to come, and I would say meaningfully so. So we expect, given the work we're doing and given the business we built and the ability of brokers to come over here and produce more than they can produce in other places and do things for their clients that is harder for them to do in other places, we expect to see that momentum continue, and it's an important part of our strategy.

How much expansion are you getting new deals versus old?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll give you a comment on it, and then I'm going to ask Jim to also, because you asked multiple questions there. But first of all, the pace of wins is picking up, and when you have more wins, you have more different kinds of wins. We're seeing more wins
componenttext: I'll give you a comment on it, and then I'm going to ask Jim to also, because you asked multiple questions there. But first of all, the pace of wins is picking up, and when you have more wins, you have more different kinds of wins. We're seeing more wins outside the U.S. than we've seen historically. We are seeing more wins in the, what I would call technical area, which makes the GWS acquisition even more appealing for us. We're seeing, on the transaction services side of the business, we're seeing wins where they're demanding that we do things that we haven't been able to do historically, and again, our GCS team and our brokerage team have worked to put people some capabilities in place to serve that requirement. So all of that is positive. And by the way, we really are seeing a lot of, as Jim commented in the numbers, a high percentage of the wins we are having are add on services or expansions of existing contracts. So the business is just getting bigger in part and all the things you see in a bigger business, more diverse types of services and contracts, more global, all of that stuff is happening for us. But Jim, do want to add anything to that?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015

componenttext: Bob, the only thing I would add to that is just, I think, as the depth and breadth of our capabilities set has continues to expand. The same thing's happened with the size, the depth and breadth of the assignment. So as we become more capable to do more things for our clients, we're seeing those opportunities open up, the clients are smart and well-informed as to our capability sets. And I think that's helped to drive largely more complicated accounts with more services and critical facilities was one that you mentioned that has picked up simply because we picked up capabilities in that area and continue to improve.

componenttext: Yes, Brandon, that's the circumstance that we're precluded from essentially selling at this point, the 2 companies until they're combined, have to market separately. componenttext: Yes, I don't think it's going to have much impact. componenttext: I just have a follow up on Norland in a more technical aspect of that business, which you cited a couple times, seems to be strong. What exactly -- or can you put a little more detail around what exactly what you do with data centers and things of that nature? So for instance, like when we hear about Amazon and their cloud business just growing so rapidly, is that something that you guys would be involved in? Or is it more to do with companies sort of more back office, if you will, data center needs. Just trying to understand exactly what gets done there.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say both. If you look at a heavy-duty data center, we would do everything within that data center up to putting the computers in the racks and from that point forward. So in some cases, we'll not only manage the facility mechanical systems,
componenttext: Well, I would say both. If you look at a heavy-duty data center, we would do everything within that data center up to putting the computers in the racks and from that point forward. So in some cases, we'll not only manage the facility mechanical systems, fire, safety, battery power back up, et cetera. But in some cases, even build out the racking systems and then that's where our service would stop. So we -- I don't know, is that helpful? Did that answer your question?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, is that, because of the nature that being more technical on the capability, do you get a better margin on that? And also, do you see that growing faster than, say, the non-technical side of things?
componenttext: Yes. I mean, is that, because of the nature that being more technical on the capability, do you get a better margin on that? And also, do you see that growing faster than, say, the non-technical side of things?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I can't comment on the margin specifically, but I would say, it's definitely one of the areas within that business where we've seen strong growth, and we have -- we had significant capabilities already in that area before the acquisition of Norland. Norla
componenttext: I can't comment on the margin specifically, but I would say, it's definitely one of the areas within that business where we've seen strong growth, and we have -- we had significant capabilities already in that area before the acquisition of Norland. Norland had a probably almost 1/3 of their business that was totally focused on these types of critical facilities. GWS has considerable focus and expertise as well and a variety of critical facilities, not only data centers but also laboratories and other critical facilities. So that, I think our base of capabilities has continued to improve and the market has been pretty open for us there.
