componenttext: Yes. Pretty much. I think you've outlined the right factors.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: And what was it that, I guess, surprised you or turned out to be a bit more positive to move from mid-single-digit to high single-digit accretion?
componenttext: And what was it that, I guess, surprised you or turned out to be a bit more positive to move from mid-single-digit to high single-digit accretion?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's 2 factors. One being increased synergy and the second just increased confidence.
componenttext: There's 2 factors. One being increased synergy and the second just increased confidence.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the synergy, I think you'd mentioned $30 million, but I thought that was the same as what it was originally and then the extra $20 million was something for 2017.
componenttext: Okay. And the synergy, I think you'd mentioned $30 million, but I thought that was the same as what it was originally and then the extra $20 million was something for 2017.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. When we first announced the deal in March, we referenced the $35 million run rate synergy and noted that we expected most of that to be back-end weighted to the second year. or not most of it, but more to be back-end weighted so that we'd realize it o
componenttext: No. When we first announced the deal in March, we referenced the $35 million run rate synergy and noted that we expected most of that to be back-end weighted to the second year. or not most of it, but more to be back-end weighted so that we'd realize it over 2 years. That $35 million run-rate synergy has now increased to $50 million. And we're saying we believe we'll achieve $30 million of that $50 million in the next calendar year in 2016. And by the end of '17, we should largely achieve the full $50 million run rate synergy. So the total amount of synergy has increased, and the pace in which we expect to achieve the synergy has increased.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then I have a question in Development Services and I guess, this as well as Investment Management. Given the -- how robust capital markets are, do you think you'll accelerate asset sales and drive, promote incentive fees and that sort of
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then I have a question in Development Services and I guess, this as well as Investment Management. Given the -- how robust capital markets are, do you think you'll accelerate asset sales and drive, promote incentive fees and that sort of stuff in the next few quarters? I noticed it seemed like your carried interest was a little higher this quarter. I'm just curious as to what your plans are with again, the development pipeline being pretty large and moving its way through and then any other asset sales that might drive promotes?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tony, you mentioned both the development business and the Investment Management business. And it has been the case for some time now and continues to be case that we're aggressively harvesting assets in our Investment Management business because that
componenttext: Yes. Tony, you mentioned both the development business and the Investment Management business. And it has been the case for some time now and continues to be case that we're aggressively harvesting assets in our Investment Management business because that's what our clients want us to do. We're able to fetch good prices and recycle the capital for them in many cases. And they're -- and generating very good relative returns. And so we'll continue down that path. In the development business, we built up a very healthy in-process portfolio of opportunities. They're very well underwritten, very good and we think that, that business will contribute really nicely to the company fourth quarter this year and next year. And we're not doing anything to accelerate it. Development projects have their own life cycle. And you have to get them approved, designed, built and leased up and then you can sell them. So we're not doing anything to accelerate that process. But that process is playing out. And as you know, we've -- our portfolio of projects is growing nicely over the last couple of years. So we expect to see some good returns as a result.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Can you share what the fourth quarter expected incentive fees or carried interest amount is going to be?
componenttext: Okay. Can you share what the fourth quarter expected incentive fees or carried interest amount is going to be?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tony, what we mentioned on our -- just before we opened up for questions, is that we expect the combination of the 2 businesses to be up moderately over last year.
componenttext: Tony, what we mentioned on our -- just before we opened up for questions, is that we expect the combination of the 2 businesses to be up moderately over last year.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just last question. If I think about your various business lines and then also your various geographies and then overlay that with some of the more macroeconomic volatility we've seen over the last few months, where do you guys see pressure
componenttext: Okay. And then just last question. If I think about your various business lines and then also your various geographies and then overlay that with some of the more macroeconomic volatility we've seen over the last few months, where do you guys see pressure, if anywhere on that matrix?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right now, Tony, we're not seeing a lot of pressure. I would tell you where we're seeing the strongest growth is in Europe. You saw the results this quarter. We expect that to continue. But we saw good growth in places where people didn't necessarily expe
componenttext: Right now, Tony, we're not seeing a lot of pressure. I would tell you where we're seeing the strongest growth is in Europe. You saw the results this quarter. We expect that to continue. But we saw good growth in places where people didn't necessarily expect it. In Greater China, we had nice growth. In Australia, we did. And so we haven't felt a lot of meaningful pressure at this point. And the backlogs and business we have suggest that there should finish out nicely for us.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brandon Dobell of William Blair.
componenttext: The next question is from Brandon Dobell of William Blair.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me keep hammering the capital markets line for a second here. Do you feel there's any -- or was any acceleration in deals with an eye of maybe uncertainty towards the end of year, people just kind of changing their approach based on how the interest r
componenttext: Let me keep hammering the capital markets line for a second here. Do you feel there's any -- or was any acceleration in deals with an eye of maybe uncertainty towards the end of year, people just kind of changing their approach based on how the interest rate noises kind of bring to the capital markets? Are people changing their trajectory? Or was it just it felt like deals that closed are -- weren't closing when they were supposed to close.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brandon, this is Jim. We did not see any change in the dynamics of people trying to accelerate deal closings. I would say that you asked about coming forward next quarter. I mean, next -- Q4 of the last 2 years has been really strong. So it's a little bit
componenttext: Brandon, this is Jim. We did not see any change in the dynamics of people trying to accelerate deal closings. I would say that you asked about coming forward next quarter. I mean, next -- Q4 of the last 2 years has been really strong. So it's a little bit of a tough compare. But outside of that, I think the business activity is still strong.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And within the U.S., looking at the larger markets versus secondary markets, I know there's still some pretty big gaps in the cap rates and things like that between those markets. Do you look at those, if you want to do between those 2 categories, w
componenttext: Okay. And within the U.S., looking at the larger markets versus secondary markets, I know there's still some pretty big gaps in the cap rates and things like that between those markets. Do you look at those, if you want to do between those 2 categories, where do you feel you've got more momentum or where do you feel the momentum is sustainable over a longer duration for your brokers?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: While there's still, honestly, an awful lot of activity across the market globally, both in the key core CBD markets and in the secondary markets. But we have seen strengthening in secondary markets, both throughout the U.S. and EMEA.
componenttext: While there's still, honestly, an awful lot of activity across the market globally, both in the key core CBD markets and in the secondary markets. But we have seen strengthening in secondary markets, both throughout the U.S. and EMEA.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in GWS, maybe some color on how the cadence of the -- either contract renewals or your opportunity to kind of get undercover some of these contracts, how we should think about that impacting some of the potential knock-on revenues around ot
componenttext: Okay. And then in GWS, maybe some color on how the cadence of the -- either contract renewals or your opportunity to kind of get undercover some of these contracts, how we should think about that impacting some of the potential knock-on revenues around other services, whether it be add-ons to the existing contracts for facility or property, leasing, maybe it's some capital markets activity, but I guess, and focus kind of more on leasing and consulting around existing contracts. Is it going to take 4, 5, 6 years to get through all these things? Or do you have opportunities to go back or to go into one of those customers kind of midstream and change what those deals might look like?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Brandon, we always have the opportunity because of the full-service nature of what we do, we talked those. And they're mostly large corporate still increasingly we're doing work for hospital systems and government enterprises. But the -- we always h
componenttext: Well, Brandon, we always have the opportunity because of the full-service nature of what we do, we talked those. And they're mostly large corporate still increasingly we're doing work for hospital systems and government enterprises. But the -- we always have the opportunity to talk to them on a full-service basis. But we've made an absolute commitment to ourselves and to our clients that for the time being, our focus for them with this acquisition, which again, as we talked about in our prepared remarks, is the biggest event in a decade, and really unlike anything in our sector. The focus is on great results for our clients. We believe that the other things we do aren't going to be a secret to them. And that over time, [indiscernible] provide of them work we do now. We'll begin -- we'll be able to integrate back and forth between the client base that we have and the client base that GWS brought to us with the very complementary services we've had. But that's not what we've talked about in our underwriting or in Jim's talked a number of times over the last couple of quarters about what we expect. What we're talking about is not that. That'll be there if we do a good job. Our focus is on doing a good job. We think there will be upside, but we aren't factoring in a lot of revenue synergy into that business right now. We're factoring in our normal growth and excellent execution. And we think the revenue synergy will come as a result of that.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Does the acquisition change how we should think about the headcount growth trajectory for '16 i.e., do you need to add service professionals in the core service lines kind of around the GWS deal to really take advantage of the breadth of the portfol
componenttext: Okay. Does the acquisition change how we should think about the headcount growth trajectory for '16 i.e., do you need to add service professionals in the core service lines kind of around the GWS deal to really take advantage of the breadth of the portfolio? Or should we expect kind of the numbers headcount you guys had in '16 to look like it did in '15 for the growth rates a little bit slower.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We won't need to add a lot of professionals. We added a lot of professionals, as you know, and really kind of at a record pace the last couple of years in our transactional businesses. And we worked for 80%, 90% of the large companies around the world on
componenttext: We won't need to add a lot of professionals. We added a lot of professionals, as you know, and really kind of at a record pace the last couple of years in our transactional businesses. And we worked for 80%, 90% of the large companies around the world on the transaction side already we're positioned to do more for those clients. We're positioned to do work for them on a contractual basis and we're seeing more of that. But we're not going to have to meaningfully ramp up our headcount to get that done.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

componenttext: Jim, I was trying to get a better idea with regards to the guidance bump. It looks like $0.03 to $0.04 of it was GWS. Mortgage some carried interest is that the way to kind of thing about the different variables that led you guys to take such a constructive view on the outlook?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say those are factors. But really, the businesses have been performing pretty strongly across all 3 regions in all lines of business. We do a bottoms-up detailed review every quarter, and it was that review that took us to this increase.
componenttext: I would say those are factors. But really, the businesses have been performing pretty strongly across all 3 regions in all lines of business. We do a bottoms-up detailed review every quarter, and it was that review that took us to this increase.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

componenttext: Great. And if I look at the balance sheet a little over 2x debt-to-EBITDA today, where do you see that factoring out as 2016 progresses? Do you see that dropping down to more normalized levels?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: When we announced the deal in March, we said we thought we would be 1.7x leverage, 1.7x EBITDA by year-end. And I think we are right on track for that. The -- that's -- even that's a relatively conservative view. So our bank covenants will show a lower le
componenttext: When we announced the deal in March, we said we thought we would be 1.7x leverage, 1.7x EBITDA by year-end. And I think we are right on track for that. The -- that's -- even that's a relatively conservative view. So our bank covenants will show a lower leverage ratio we can pro forma in the run-rate EBITDA that we've acquired, et cetera. But on the most conservative view, we're just over 2 now and we'll be under 2 by year-end.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just 2 quick ones, 2 more quick ones for me. One in terms of retention GWS. It sounds like you said you guys have the business leaders in place and the management in place. How did you guys -- do you see any loss in terms of some of the ke
componenttext: Great. And then just 2 quick ones, 2 more quick ones for me. One in terms of retention GWS. It sounds like you said you guys have the business leaders in place and the management in place. How did you guys -- do you see any loss in terms of some of the key personnel that you guys were expecting to take on?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the most important people have signed employment agreements 4, 5 years and are showing quite significant enthusiasm for the business from the combination. So I don't think so. We will have -- there will be some overlapping. So there will be some peo
componenttext: Well, the most important people have signed employment agreements 4, 5 years and are showing quite significant enthusiasm for the business from the combination. So I don't think so. We will have -- there will be some overlapping. So there will be some people that leave. But I think we're in a very strong shape there as far as retention.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And now that this deal has been completed, are you seeing -- are you guys going to be now focusing back on some of the smaller tuck-in and strategic acquisitions?
componenttext: Great. And now that this deal has been completed, are you seeing -- are you guys going to be now focusing back on some of the smaller tuck-in and strategic acquisitions?

componenttext: Yes. I think you'll start to see pickup as early as our next quarterly call.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from David Ridley-Lane with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from David Ridley-Lane with Bank of America.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: So one concern we've heard from investors is that sources cross-border capital either commodity-driven economies or greater Asia economies are likely to slow going forward. What have you seen, either quantitatively or anecdotally about cross-border capita
componenttext: So one concern we've heard from investors is that sources cross-border capital either commodity-driven economies or greater Asia economies are likely to slow going forward. What have you seen, either quantitatively or anecdotally about cross-border capital flows?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have not seen that, David. What we've seen is that cross-border capital flows have remained strong. We've interviewed kind of pooled our clients in various ways. We think half of the clients that we did business with a year ago that were moving capital
componenttext: We have not seen that, David. What we've seen is that cross-border capital flows have remained strong. We've interviewed kind of pooled our clients in various ways. We think half of the clients that we did business with a year ago that were moving capital across borders. Half of them intend to move more capital this year than they did a year ago. And so you saw the numbers for the -- numbers not only for us, but for the whole market for the quarter and the year. So we have not seen a pullback in that at this point. It just hasn't been something we've seen. And in Europe, in particular, we've seen a meaningful increase in cross-border flows in the year.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on the capital markets pipeline, as the disruption we've seen in sort of a depth markets and around in particular, has that been enough to put some deals out of the pipeline? Or as most of things that you've been working on still very muc
componenttext: Got it. And then on the capital markets pipeline, as the disruption we've seen in sort of a depth markets and around in particular, has that been enough to put some deals out of the pipeline? Or as most of things that you've been working on still very much go ahead for the fourth quarter?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. From what we've seen, there's sufficient capital from other sources to step in. So again, as I mentioned earlier, we have been anticipating that the rate of growth in sales will come down to a more sustainable level. And we still believe that that's
componenttext: Yes. From what we've seen, there's sufficient capital from other sources to step in. So again, as I mentioned earlier, we have been anticipating that the rate of growth in sales will come down to a more sustainable level. And we still believe that that's likely to be the case. But we're not seeing deals die basically because of the lack of debt capital.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then kind of curious on the leasing volumes. Do you -- did you see any impact from the market volatility? Or were corporations pretty had enough confidence to go ahead and execute leases, even with some of the broader market volatility in the
componenttext: Got it. And then kind of curious on the leasing volumes. Do you -- did you see any impact from the market volatility? Or were corporations pretty had enough confidence to go ahead and execute leases, even with some of the broader market volatility in the quarter?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We saw strong growth in leasing around the world, slightly slower growth in the U.S. than we've seen, but still very strong at 9%. And so we haven't seen the dynamic. We're expecting to see some of that in China, but we really haven't, as of now, haven't
componenttext: We saw strong growth in leasing around the world, slightly slower growth in the U.S. than we've seen, but still very strong at 9%. And so we haven't seen the dynamic. We're expecting to see some of that in China, but we really haven't, as of now, haven't seen that pullback. And we're expecting to see a nice finish to the year. We are all watching China like everybody else.

componenttext:

I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Steve Iaco, Investor Relations for CBRE. Thank you, Mr. Iaco. You may now begin.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This conference call
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This conference call is being webcast through the Investor Relations section of our website. You can also find there a presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks. And the audio archive of the webcast will be posted to the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow.
Before we get started, we would like to remind all of you that we will host our Annual Business Outlook Day in New York on December 3. This is an opportunity to provide the investment community with an in-depth understanding of our business lines and our strategy. We look forward to seeing many of you there.
Now please turn to the slide labeled Forward-looking Statements. This presentation contain statements that are forward-looking within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, financial performance, business outlook and adjusted earnings per share expectations, including expected contributions and cost synergies from the newly acquired Global Workplace Solutions business and its integration. These statements should be considered to be estimates only, and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we will undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any forward-looking statements we may make today. For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our third quarter earnings report filed on Form 8-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q filed in 2015 and most -- and our most recent annual report on Form 10-K. These reports are filed with the SEC and available at sec.gov.
During this presentation, we may make certain statements that refer to non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC regulations. We are required by these regulations, we provide reconciliation to these measures to what we believe to be the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Those reconciliations, together with the explanations of these measures, can be found within the appendix of this presentation.
Please turn to Slide 3. Participating on our call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our CFO; and Gil Borok, our Deputy CFO and Chief Accounting Officer.
During our remarks, except where otherwise noted, all references to the percentage increase or decrease are in local currency as calculated by comparing current-period results at prior-period exchange rates versus prior-period results.
Now please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. The third quarter of 2015 was an eventful period for CBRE. As you saw in our press release, we posted excellent results with strong top and bottom line growth around the world, highlig
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. The third quarter of 2015 was an eventful period for CBRE. As you saw in our press release, we posted excellent results with strong top and bottom line growth around the world, highlighted by a 28% increase in adjusted earnings per share.
We also moved decisively to fortify our market-leading occupier outsourcing business with the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions on September 1. This is our largest acquisition in nearly a decade and one of the most compelling ever completed in our sector. The combination creates a platform unlike anything that has previously existed in our industry with highly complementary product offerings and common cultures around innovation and client service. It broadens our value proposition, creates true global scale, deepens our relationships with prominent global corporations and enriches our talent pool.
Our last 3 large strategic acquisitions are recurring revenue businesses that operate under contracts that are typically 5 years or longer. These acquisitions have helped to transform CBRE into a more resilient business. We now have a dramatically more powerful integrated service offering, while maintaining our core focus on commercial real estate services.
We also continue to make gains through investments in recruiting, training, technology, branding and research, all positioned to help us deliver great outcomes for clients and to drive growth. We saw the payoff from these investments across CBRE in the third quarter. Notably, our services business, comprised of the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific regions, again posted significant revenue in normalized EBITDA growth with solid margin expansion. Our Investment Management business also performed well.
Now Jim will provide you with more specific insight into our performance.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. I will begin with an update on our overall performance and the expected contributions from our recent acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions.Please turn to Slide 5. In Q3, our business continued to exhibit excellent broad-based moment
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. I will begin with an update on our overall performance and the expected contributions from our recent acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions.
Please turn to Slide 5. In Q3, our business continued to exhibit excellent broad-based momentum. Revenue and earnings growth for the quarter was very strong. In local currency, gross revenue increased 26% while fee revenue rose 21%. Without the 1-month contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, gross and fee revenue were both up 16% in local currency. Normalized EBITDA totaled $345 million, an 18% improvement from last year's Q3, or a 24% improvement in local currency. Profitability was strong with a 17.8% normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue, up approximately 60 basis points from Q3 2014. Adjusted earnings per share increased 28% to $0.51 for the quarter.
Please turn to Slide 6 for an update on the expected financial contributions from the newly acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. This acquisition greatly enhanced our ability to serve leading corporations around the world. We funded about 1/3 of the purchase price, price with cash and temporary revolver borrowings and 2/3 with attractively priced 5- and 7-year bank debt and 10-year bonds. Both Moody's and Standard & Poor's affirmed our investment-grade credit rating.
The integration of Global Workplace Solutions with our existing occupier outsourcing business is off to a great start. Morale is very high. Our organization structure for senior leadership, line of business leaders and geographic leadership is in place. Feedback from clients, their consultants and our shareholders has been overwhelmingly positive as the rationale for the acquisition and the value proposition is clear.
We have identified additional cost synergies and now expect run rate annual synergies of approximately $50 million, up from our initial estimate of $35 million in March 2015. We anticipate achieving approximately $30 million of the synergy in 2016, with the remaining run rate savings largely realized by year end 2017.
When we announced the acquisition in March, we indicated expected material accretion to our adjusted 2016 EPS with a mid-single-digit percentage increase. We are now raising our estimate to high single-digit percentage increase accretion in 2016.
We closed the acquisition in the early part of our expected time frame and raised financing with minimal interest expense in advance of closing. In light of this, we now expect the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business to contribute $0.03 to $0.04 to adjusted earnings per share for the last 4 months of 2015.
Calendar year Q4 has typically been a seasonally slower period for the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business due to its fiscal year previously ending September 30. As a result, accretion from the last 4 months of 2015 is not indicative of the higher expected run rate contribution in 2016.
Please turn to Slide 7 for a review of the performance of our major global lines of business in Q3. As a reminder, I am referencing percentage increases in local currency, unless noted otherwise. For the company as a whole, contractual fee revenue plus leasing, which is largely recurring, totaled 68% of total fee revenue. Occupier outsourcing showed strong growth in all 3 regions, excluding transaction revenue generated by this business, which is accounted for in leasing and sales revenue. Occupier outsourcing achieved a 53% increase in fee revenue. Excluding the contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, fee revenue rose 14%.
Asset Services growth was moderate with fee revenue up 4%. Investment Management performed well. Fee revenue increased 19%, fueled by a higher carried interest tied to property dispositions. Valuation again grew nicely with global fee revenue up 14%. We benefited from higher volumes of appraisal and consulting work, which stem in part from acquisitions we made in 2014.
Property leasing revenue again rose by double digits with 12% growth globally led by Europe and Asia Pacific. The growth rate in the U.S. slowed modestly but remained strong at 9%. We are seeing less available -- availability in Class A office space in a few gateway markets with new development accelerating, but generally still lagging demand. This may extend the time it takes to complete certain larger lease transactions. However, we continue to reap the benefits of a very strong recruiting activity, higher productivity from our existing brokerage teams and modest rent growth.
Our capital markets business continue to perform exceptionally well amid gains in market share and strong capital flows into real estate. Property sales revenue rose 19% with every region producing markedly higher activity.
In the U.S., we logged impressive market share gains as confirmed by our CA at a time when the overall market activity was flat for the quarter. We continue to see activity broadening in the secondary markets in the U.S. and EMEA. In Asia Pacific, Australia and Hong Kong accounted for the lion's share of the increase.
Mortgage services also remained robust with revenue up 33%. Even though as expected, loan volume with the U.S. government-sponsored Enterprises leveled off due to the regulatory caps. Banks, life companies and other debt capital sources stepped up their lending.
Please turn to Slide 8, where we will review Q3 results for our 3 regional services segments, all in local currency.
Fee revenue increased 18% in the Americas. In EMEA, fee revenue increased 29%. We saw healthy gains across the region, including France, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. In Asia Pacific, fee revenue rose 22% with growth led by Australia, Greater China and India. Fee revenue growth, without the contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, was 14% in the Americas, 19% in EMEA and 17% in Asia Pacific. Normalized EBITDA increased 18% in the Americas, 70% in EMEA and 54% in Asia Pacific.
Please turn to Slide 9, regarding our occupier outsourcing business, which is reported within the 3 regional services segments. This business line, which we previously called Global Corporate Services, adopted the Global Workplace Solution name on September 1. This move reflects Global Workplace Solutions' high-brand value in the facility management sector and the increasingly diverse workspaces in which we are serving clients, including hospitals, data centers, labs and manufacturing plants. Outsourcing continues to gain wider appeal, and existing customers are taking advantage of our deeper and broader platform. In Q3, we set a new quarterly record for the number of expansions of existing contractual relationships. We also signed 9 contracts with new or existing health care clients, reflecting the compelling and growing opportunity for CBRE in this sector. These numbers did not include contracts from the newly acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, which we will begin to reflect in our contract reporting in 2016.
Please turn to Slide 10, regarding our Global Investment Management segment. This business performed well with $19 million of carried interest tied to significant property disposition activity. Capital raising totaled $1.8 billion in Q3 and $7 billion over the trailing 4 quarters. We continue to attract significant equity commitments based on the solid performance of our investment programs within 75% of our AUM as outperformed its long-term industry benchmark.
At the end of Q3, Assets Under Management of $86 billion were up $1.6 billion over prior year Q3 in local currency, but down $2.6 billion when converted into U.S. dollars.
Please turn to Slide 11 regarding our Development Services segment. Pro forma revenue, which includes equity, earnings and gains on real estate sales and EBITDA, both declined reflecting fewer large property dispositions than in last year's highly active Q3 period. However, activity is very strong, and we expect most of this year's earnings to be achieved in Q4 from several large transactions. We now anticipate that our combined Investment Management and Development Services businesses for 2015 will moderately exceed 2014 performance. Development projects in process totaled $6.7 billion, up $1.3 billion since the end of 2014. The pipeline totaled $4 billion, flat with year-end 2014 as projects have been converted from pipeline to in-process.
Now please turn to Slide 12 as I turn the call back over to Bob for closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. As we enter Q4, 2015 is clearly emerging as another exceptional year for CBRE. The actions we have taken to upgrade our talent base, enhance our service offering, materially strengthen our operating platform, particularly around data and t
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. As we enter Q4, 2015 is clearly emerging as another exceptional year for CBRE. The actions we have taken to upgrade our talent base, enhance our service offering, materially strengthen our operating platform, particularly around data and technology and fortify our financial position are yielding strong results for our clients and for our shareholders. We are mindful of the challenges to the global economy. However, in light of our performance through the third quarter and our strategic and financial momentum, we're raising our full year 2015 guidance for adjusted EPS by $0.10 to the $2 to $2.05 range. This new guidance implies 20% year-on-year growth in adjusted earnings per share at the midpoint of the range.
With that, operator, we'll go to questions.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

componenttext: I want to start with property sales. The growth was obviously strong in the U.S. certainly versus what a lot of us were expecting when we look at the RCA data. And you had called out that you had taken share in the quarter. But I was hoping you could break down how much of the growth that you saw in Q3 was share gain versus maybe the market holding up a little bit better than what the third-party data would indicate. And to the extent that you're gaining share, if you could touch on some of the things that would be driving that.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

componenttext: And is that an increase in headcount or recruiting or better productivity or a combination of the 2?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brad, this is Bob. It's both. We've had a lot of recruiting success. That's been a big initiative for us for the last 3 years. And we've talked about the fact that we've had -- a couple years ago was one of the best years in the history, if not the best y
componenttext: Brad, this is Bob. It's both. We've had a lot of recruiting success. That's been a big initiative for us for the last 3 years. And we've talked about the fact that we've had -- a couple years ago was one of the best years in the history, if not the best year in the history of our company. We repeated it last year. This year is on a similar pace, and we're starting to see the benefit of that recruiting. We are seeing better production from some of our people. We're teeming in some ways in doing some things we've built in in-house investment banking capability to support our investment sales professionals. That's been helpful in a number of cases. And as a result, all of this came together to produce what you saw this quarter. I think it's notable, though, what Jim said, these things do fluctuate quarter-to-quarter. This was a particularly good quarter for us.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And with the capital markets business, I know it's been something that we've been nervous on. I was hoping that you can give us some thoughts about how that business is shaping up looking forward. And also, whether you're starting to
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And with the capital markets business, I know it's been something that we've been nervous on. I was hoping that you can give us some thoughts about how that business is shaping up looking forward. And also, whether you're starting to see any sort of pullback in the credit markets.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brad, this is Jim. We -- at the beginning of the year, as you know, we gave guidance that we thought the growth rate in this business would go back to high single digits. We think we -- obviously, the market -- we and the market have outperformed that pro
componenttext: Brad, this is Jim. We -- at the beginning of the year, as you know, we gave guidance that we thought the growth rate in this business would go back to high single digits. We think we -- obviously, the market -- we and the market have outperformed that projection. But we still believe that, that business will slow down and that that's coming and we may have just been a little bit early on that call. We think it'll slowdown at a more sustainable level. But that continues to be our belief. This -- the rate of increase and liquidity in the market has come down. But as you know, there's still quite a bit of liquidity in the market.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And I guess last one. Just sticking with capital markets with the commercial mortgage business. In the last quarter, you had said there was a $15 million headwind to EBITDA that you were expecting Q3, Q4 due to the GSE lending caps. And it certainly doesn't seem to have impacted the third quarter. So was wondering whether that was still the case. And if you were able to beat that, what would be driving it?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: That ended up being about flat for Q3. We are still projecting that Q4 will be down from prior year. We're now thinking plus or minus $10 million. But it's a little hard to project those numbers precisely. Other lenders have picked up pace. More capitals
componenttext: That ended up being about flat for Q3. We are still projecting that Q4 will be down from prior year. We're now thinking plus or minus $10 million. But it's a little hard to project those numbers precisely. Other lenders have picked up pace. More capitals come into market from other sources as they've pulled back.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. When we first announced the deal in March, we referenced the $35 million run rate synergy and noted that we expected most of that to be back-end weighted to the second year -- not most of it but for it to be more back-end weighted so that we'd realize
componenttext: No. When we first announced the deal in March, we referenced the $35 million run rate synergy and noted that we expected most of that to be back-end weighted to the second year -- not most of it but for it to be more back-end weighted so that we'd realize that over 2 years. That $35 million run-rate synergy has now increased to $50 million. And we're saying we believe we'll achieve $30 million of that $50 million in the next calendar year in 2016. And by the end of '17, we should largely achieve the full $50 million run rate synergy. So the total amount of synergy has increased, and the pace in which we expect to achieve the synergy has increased.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then I have a question in Development Services and I guess as well as Investment Management. Given the -- how robust capital markets are, do you think you'll accelerate asset sales and drive, promote incentive fees and that sort of stuff
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then I have a question in Development Services and I guess as well as Investment Management. Given the -- how robust capital markets are, do you think you'll accelerate asset sales and drive, promote incentive fees and that sort of stuff in the next few quarters? I noticed that it seemed like your carried interest was a little higher this quarter. I'm just curious as to what your plans are with again, the development pipeline being pretty large and moving its way through and then any other asset sales that might drive promotes?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tony, you mentioned both the development business and the Investment Management business. And it has been the case for some time now and continues to be case that we're aggressively harvesting assets in our Investment Management business because that
componenttext: Yes. Tony, you mentioned both the development business and the Investment Management business. And it has been the case for some time now and continues to be case that we're aggressively harvesting assets in our Investment Management business because that's what our clients want us to do. We're able to fetch good prices and recycle the capital for them in many cases. And they're -- and generating very good relative returns. And so we'll continue down that path. In the development business, we built up a very healthy in-process portfolio of opportunities. They're very well underwritten, very good and we think that, that business will contribute really nicely to the company fourth quarter this year and next year. And we're not doing anything to accelerate it. Development projects have their own life cycle. And you have to get them approved, designed, built and leased up and then you can sell them. So we're not doing anything to accelerate that process. But that process is playing out. And as you know, we've -- our portfolio of projects has grown nicely over the last couple of years. So we expect to see some good returns as a result.

componenttext: Right now, Tony, we're not seeing a lot of pressure. I would tell you where we're seeing the strongest growth is in Europe. You saw the results this quarter. We expect that to continue. But we saw good growth in places where people didn't necessarily expect it. In Greater China, we had nice growth. In Australia, we did. And so we haven't felt a lot of meaningful pressure at this point. And the backlogs and business we have suggest that the year should finish out nicely for us.

componenttext: Well, there's still, honestly, an awful lot of activity across the market globally, both in this key core CBD markets and in the secondary markets. But we have seen strengthening in the secondary markets, both throughout the U.S. and EMEA.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in GWS, maybe some color on how the cadence of the either contract renewals or your opportunity to kind of get under the covers of some of these contracts, how we should think about that impacting some of the potential knock-on revenues aro
componenttext: Okay. And then in GWS, maybe some color on how the cadence of the either contract renewals or your opportunity to kind of get under the covers of some of these contracts, how we should think about that impacting some of the potential knock-on revenues around other services, whether it be add-ons to the existing contracts for facility or property, leasing. Maybe it's some capital markets activity, but I guess I'd focus kind of more on leasing and consulting around existing contracts. Is it going to take you 4, 5, 6 years to get through all these things? Or do you have opportunities to go back or to go into one of those customers kind of midstream and change what those deals might look like?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Brandon, we always have the opportunity because of the full-service nature of what we do to talked those, and they're mostly large corporates. Though, increasingly, we're doing work for hospital systems and government enterprises. But the -- we alwa
componenttext: Well, Brandon, we always have the opportunity because of the full-service nature of what we do to talked those, and they're mostly large corporates. Though, increasingly, we're doing work for hospital systems and government enterprises. But the -- we always have the opportunity to talk to them on a full-service basis. But we've made an absolute commitment to ourselves and to our clients that for the time being, our focus for them with this acquisition, which again, as we talked about in our prepared remarks, is the biggest we've done in a decade. And really unlike anything we spend in our sector, the focus is on great results for our clients. We believe that the other things we do aren't going to be a secret to them. And that over time, [indiscernible] provide great service to them with the work we do now. We'll begin -- we'll be able to integrate back and forth between the client base that we have and the client base that GWS brought to us with the very complementary services we've had. But that's not what we've talked about in our underwriting or -- and Jim's talked a number of times over the last couple of quarters about what we expect out of this deal. What we're talking about is not that. That will be there if we do a good job. Our focus is on doing a good job. We think there will be upside, but we aren't factoring in a lot of revenue synergy into that business right now. We're factoring in our normal growth and excellent execution. And we think the revenue synergy will come as a result of that.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015

componenttext: Okay. Does the acquisition change how we should think about the headcount growth trajectory for '16 i.e., do you need to add service professionals in the core service lines kind of around the GWS deal to really take advantage of the breadth of the portfolio? Or should we expect kind of the numbers of headcount you guys had in '16 to look like it did in '15 so the growth rate is a little bit slower?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we won't need to add a lot of professionals. We added a lot of professionals, as you know, and really kind of at a record pace the last couple of years in our transactional businesses. And we worked for 80%, 90% of the large companies around the worl
componenttext: Yes, we won't need to add a lot of professionals. We added a lot of professionals, as you know, and really kind of at a record pace the last couple of years in our transactional businesses. And we worked for 80%, 90% of the large companies around the world on the transaction side already. We're positioned to do more for those clients. We're positioned to do work for them on a contractual basis and we're seeing more of that. But we're not going to have to meaningfully ramp up our headcount to get that done.

componenttext: When we announced the deal in March, we said we thought we would be at 1.7x leverage, 1.7x EBITDA by year end. And I think we are right on track for that. componenttextpreview: So one concern we've heard from investors is that sources of cross-border capital either commodity-driven economies or greater Asia economies are likely to slow going forward. What have you seen, either quantitatively or anecdotally, about cross-border ca
componenttext: So one concern we've heard from investors is that sources of cross-border capital either commodity-driven economies or greater Asia economies are likely to slow going forward. What have you seen, either quantitatively or anecdotally, about cross-border capital flows?

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: We have not seen that, David. What we've seen is that cross-border capital flows have remained strong. We've interviewed kind of, polled our clients in various ways. We think half of the clients that we did business with a year ago that were moving capita
componenttext: We have not seen that, David. What we've seen is that cross-border capital flows have remained strong. We've interviewed kind of, polled our clients in various ways. We think half of the clients that we did business with a year ago that were moving capital across borders, half of them intend to move more capital this year than they did a year ago. And so you saw the numbers for the -- numbers not only for us, but for the whole market for the quarter and the year. So we have not seen a pullback in that at this point. It just hasn't been something we've seen. And in Europe, in particular, we've seen a meaningful increase in cross-border flows into Europe.

componenttext: We saw strong growth in leasing around the world, slightly slower growth in the U.S. this quarter than we've seen, but still very strong at 9%. And so we haven't seen the dynamic. headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Steve Iaco, Investor Relations for CBRE. Thank y
componenttext:
Greetings, and welcome to the CBRE Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Steve Iaco, Investor Relations for CBRE. Thank you, Mr. Iaco. You may now begin.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This conference call
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to CBRE's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Earlier today, we issued a press release announcing our financial results for the quarter. This release is posted on the homepage of our website, cbre.com. This conference call is being webcast through the Investor Relations section of our website. You can also find there a presentation slide deck, which you can use to follow along with our prepared remarks. And the audio archive of the webcast will be posted to the website later today, and a transcript of our call will be posted tomorrow.
Before we get started, we would like to remind all of you that we will host our Annual Business Outlook Day in New York on December 3. This is an opportunity to provide the investment community with an in-depth understanding of our business lines and our strategy. We look forward to seeing many of you there.
Now please turn to the slide labeled Forward-looking Statements. This presentation contains statements that are forward-looking within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These include statements regarding CBRE's future growth momentum, operations, financial performance, business outlook and adjusted earnings per share expectations, including expected contributions and cost synergies from the newly acquired Global Workplace Solutions business and its integration. These statements should be considered to be estimates only, and actual results may ultimately differ from these estimates. Except to the extent required by securities laws, we will undertake no obligation to update or publicly revise any forward-looking statements we may make today. For a full discussion of the risks and other factors that may impact any forward-looking statements, please refer to our third quarter earnings report filed on Form 8-K and our quarterly reports on Form 10-Q filed in 2015 and most -- and our most recent annual report on Form 10-K. These reports are filed with the SEC and available at sec.gov.
During this presentation, we may make certain statements that refer to non-GAAP financial measures as defined by SEC regulations. Where required by these regulations, we provide reconciliation to these measures to what we believe to be the most directly comparable GAAP measures. Those reconciliations, together with the explanations of these measures, can be found within the appendix of this presentation.
Please turn to Slide 3. Participating on our call today are Bob Sulentic, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Jim Groch, our CFO; and Gil Borok, our Deputy CFO and Chief Accounting Officer.
During our remarks, except where otherwise noted, all references to the percentage increase or decrease are in local currency as calculated by comparing current-period results at prior-period exchange rates versus prior-period results.
Now please turn to Slide 4 as I turn the call over to Bob.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steve. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. The third quarter of 2015 was an eventful period for CBRE. As you saw in our press release, we posted excellent results with strong top and bottom line growth around the world, highlig
componenttext:
Thank you, Steve. Good afternoon, everyone, and thanks for joining us. The third quarter of 2015 was an eventful period for CBRE. As you saw in our press release, we posted excellent results with strong top and bottom line growth around the world, highlighted by a 28% increase in adjusted earnings per share.
We also moved decisively to fortify our market-leading occupier outsourcing business with the acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions on September 1. This is our largest acquisition in nearly a decade and one of the most compelling ever completed in our sector. The combination creates a platform unlike anything that has previously existed in our industry, with highly complementary product offerings and common cultures around innovation and client service. It broadens our value proposition, creates true global scale, deepens our relationships with prominent global corporations and enriches our talent pool.
Our last 3 large strategic acquisitions are recurring revenue businesses that operate under contracts that are typically 5 years or longer. These acquisitions have helped to transform CBRE into a more resilient business. We now have a dramatically more powerful integrated service offering, while maintaining our core focus on commercial real estate services.
We also continue to make gains through investments in recruiting, training, technology, branding and research, all positioned to help us deliver great outcomes for clients and to drive growth. We saw the payoff from these investments across CBRE in the third quarter. Notably, our services business, comprised of the Americas, EMEA and Asia Pacific regions, again posted significant revenue in normalized EBITDA growth with solid margin expansion. Our Investment Management business also performed well.
Now Jim will provide you with more specific insight into our performance.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob. I will begin with an update on our overall performance and the expected contributions from our recent acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions.Please turn to Slide 5. In Q3, our business continued to exhibit excellent broad-based moment
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob. I will begin with an update on our overall performance and the expected contributions from our recent acquisition of Global Workplace Solutions.
Please turn to Slide 5. In Q3, our business continued to exhibit excellent broad-based momentum. Revenue and earnings growth for the quarter was very strong. In local currency, gross revenue increased 26% while fee revenue rose 21%. Without the 1-month contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, gross and fee revenue were both up 16% in local currency. Normalized EBITDA totaled $345 million, an 18% improvement from last year's Q3, or a 24% improvement in local currency. Profitability was strong with a 17.8% normalized EBITDA margin on fee revenue, up approximately 60 basis points from Q3 2014. Adjusted earnings per share increased 28% to $0.51 for the quarter.
Please turn to Slide 6 for an update on the expected financial contributions from the newly acquired Global Workplace Solutions business. This acquisition greatly enhanced our ability to serve leading corporations around the world. We funded about 1/3 of the purchase price, price with cash and temporary revolver borrowings and 2/3 with attractively priced 5- and 7-year bank debt and 10-year bonds. Both Moody's and Standard & Poor's affirmed our investment-grade credit rating.
The integration of Global Workplace Solutions with our existing occupier outsourcing business is off to a great start. Morale is very high. Our organization structure for senior leadership, line of business leaders and geographic leadership is in place. Feedback from clients, their consultants and our shareholders has been overwhelmingly positive as the rationale for the acquisition and the value proposition is clear.
We have identified additional cost synergies and now expect run rate annual synergies of approximately $50 million, up from our initial estimate of $35 million in March 2015. We anticipate achieving approximately $30 million of the synergy in 2016, with the remaining run rate savings largely realized by year end 2017.
When we announced the acquisition in March, we indicated expected material accretion to our adjusted 2016 EPS with a mid-single-digit percentage increase. We are now raising our estimate to high single-digit percentage increase accretion in 2016.
We closed the acquisition in the early part of our expected time frame and raised financing with minimal interest expense in advance of closing. In light of this, we now expect the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business to contribute $0.03 to $0.04 to adjusted earnings per share for the last 4 months of 2015.
Calendar year Q4 has typically been a seasonally slower period for the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business due to its fiscal year previously ending September 30. As a result, accretion from the last 4 months of 2015 is not indicative of the higher expected run rate contribution in 2016.
Please turn to Slide 7 for a review of the performance of our major global lines of business in Q3. As a reminder, I am referencing percentage increases in local currency, unless noted otherwise. For the company as a whole, contractual fee revenue plus leasing, which is largely recurring, totaled 68% of total fee revenue. Occupier outsourcing showed strong growth in all 3 regions, excluding transaction revenue generated by this business, which is accounted for in leasing and sales revenue. Occupier outsourcing achieved a 53% increase in fee revenue. Excluding the contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, fee revenue rose 14%.
Asset Services growth was moderate with fee revenue up 4%. Investment Management performed well. Fee revenue increased 19%, fueled by a higher carried interest tied to property dispositions. Valuation again grew nicely with global fee revenue up 14%. We benefited from higher volumes of appraisal and consulting work, which stem in part from acquisitions we made in 2014.
Property leasing revenue again rose by double digits with 12% growth globally led by Europe and Asia Pacific. The growth rate in the U.S. slowed modestly but remained strong at 9%. We are seeing less available -- availability in Class A office space in a few gateway markets with new development accelerating, but generally still lagging demand. This may extend the time it takes to complete certain larger lease transactions. However, we continue to reap the benefits of a very strong recruiting activity, higher productivity from our existing brokerage teams and modest rent growth.
Our capital markets business continue to perform exceptionally well amid gains in market share and strong capital flows into real estate. Property sales revenue rose 19% with every region producing markedly higher activity.
In the U.S., we logged impressive market share gains as confirmed by RCA at a time when the overall market activity was flat for the quarter. We continue to see activity broadening in the secondary markets in the U.S. and EMEA. In Asia Pacific, Australia and Hong Kong accounted for the lion's share of the increase.
Mortgage services also remained robust with revenue up 33%. Even though as expected, loan volume with the U.S. government-sponsored Enterprises leveled off due to the regulatory caps. Banks, life companies and other debt capital sources stepped up their lending.
Please turn to Slide 8, where we will review Q3 results for our 3 regional services segments, all in local currency.
Fee revenue increased 18% in the Americas. In EMEA, fee revenue increased 29%. We saw healthy gains across the region, including France, Germany, the Netherlands, Spain, Switzerland and the United Kingdom. In Asia Pacific, fee revenue rose 22% with growth led by Australia, Greater China and India. Fee revenue growth, without the contribution from the acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, was 14% in the Americas, 19% in EMEA and 17% in Asia Pacific. Normalized EBITDA increased 18% in the Americas, 70% in EMEA and 54% in Asia Pacific.
Please turn to Slide 9, regarding our occupier outsourcing business, which is reported within the 3 regional services segments. This business line, which we previously called Global Corporate Services, adopted the Global Workplace Solution name on September 1. This move reflects Global Workplace Solutions' high-brand value in the facility management sector and the increasingly diverse workspaces in which we are serving clients, including hospitals, data centers, labs and manufacturing plants. Outsourcing continues to gain wider appeal, and existing customers are taking advantage of our deeper and broader platform. In Q3, we set a new quarterly record for the number of expansions of existing contractual relationships. We also signed 9 contracts with new or existing health care clients, reflecting the compelling and growing opportunity for CBRE in this sector. These numbers did not include contracts from the newly acquired Global Workplace Solutions business, which we will begin to reflect in our contract reporting in 2016.
Please turn to Slide 10, regarding our Global Investment Management segment. This business performed well with $19 million of carried interest tied to significant property disposition activity. Capital raising totaled $1.8 billion in Q3 and $7 billion over the trailing 4 quarters. We continue to attract significant equity commitments based on the solid performance of our investment programs. More than 75% of our AUM has outperformed its long-term industry benchmark.
At the end of Q3, Assets Under Management of $86 billion were up $1.6 billion over prior year Q3 in local currency, but down $2.6 billion when converted into U.S. dollars.
Please turn to Slide 11 regarding our Development Services segment. Pro forma revenue, which includes equity, earnings and gains on real estate sales, and EBITDA both declined, reflecting fewer large property dispositions than in last year's highly active Q3 period. However, activity is very strong, and we expect most of this year's earnings to be achieved in Q4 from several large transactions. We now anticipate that our combined Investment Management and Development Services businesses for 2015 will moderately exceed 2014 performance. Development projects in process totaled $6.7 billion, up $1.3 billion since the end of 2014. The pipeline totaled $4 billion, flat with year-end 2014 as projects have been converted from pipeline to in-process.
Now please turn to Slide 12 as I turn the call back over to Bob for closing remarks.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. As we enter Q4, 2015 is clearly emerging as another exceptional year for CBRE. The actions we have taken to upgrade our talent base, enhance our service offering, materially strengthen our operating platform, particularly around data and t
componenttext:
Thank you, Jim. As we enter Q4, 2015 is clearly emerging as another exceptional year for CBRE. The actions we have taken to upgrade our talent base, enhance our service offering, materially strengthen our operating platform, particularly around data and technology and fortify our financial position are yielding strong results for our clients and for our shareholders. We are mindful of the challenges to the global economy. However, in light of our performance through the third quarter and our strategic and financial momentum, we're raising our full year 2015 guidance for adjusted EPS by $0.10 to the $2 to $2.05 range. This new guidance implies 20% year-on-year growth in adjusted earnings per share at the midpoint of the range.
With that, operator, we'll go to questions.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Brad Burke of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from Brad Burke of Goldman Sachs.

headline: CBRE Group, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to start with property sales. The growth was obviously strong in the U.S. certainly versus what a lot of us were expecting when we look at the RCA data. And you had called out that you had taken share in the quarter. But I was hoping you could brea
componenttext: I want to start with property sales. The growth was obviously strong in the U.S. certainly versus what a lot of us were expecting when we look at the RCA data. And you had called out that you had taken share in the quarter. But I was hoping you could break down how much of the growth that you saw in Q3 was share gain versus maybe the market holding up a little bit better than what the third-party data would indicate. And to the extent that you're gaining share, if you could touch on some of the things that would be driving that.
